item.title: Israel strikes inside Iran, sources say
item.description: A person familiar with the situation told NBC News that Israel carried out an operation in Iran. Earlier, Israeli officials notified U.S. officials that a response was coming.

media:content.media:text: middle east map Israel Iran

item.title: Israel carries out operation inside Iran, says source familiar
item.description: NBC News' Courtney Kube reports that a source familiar says Israel did carry out an operation in Iran after reports of explosions in the Isfahan area, and that Israeli officials did inform the U.S. of their intention to carry out a response in coming days.

media:content.media:title: Israel carries out operation inside Iran, says source familiar
media:content.media:description: NBC News' Courtney Kube reports that a source familiar says Israel did carry out an operation in Iran after reports of explosions in the Isfahan area, and that Israeli officials did inform the U.S. of their intention to carry out a response in coming days.

item.title: Hezbollah's second-in-command insists it is not seeking war, but would respond to Israeli escalation
item.dc:creator: Matt Bradley and Ziad Jaber and Natasha Lebedeva
item.description: Iran-backed Hezbollah wants to avoid a regional war but will respond in kind to any Israeli escalation, Naim Qassem told NBC News in an exclusive interview.

media:content.media:text: Hezbollah deputy leader Naim Qassem
media:content.media:description: Naim Qassem, the Shia Lebanese cleric and politician, who is the second-in-command of Hezbollah, speak with NBC News on April 18, 2024.

item.title: CIA director: Iranian attack on Israel was a 'spectacular failure'
item.dc:creator: Dan De Luce
item.description: CIA Director William Burns says Iran’s attack on Israel “turned out to be a spectacular failure” and that the U.S. hopes tensions in the region will ease.

media:content.media:text: CIA Director William Burns
media:content.media:description: CIA Director William Burns on Capitol Hill on March 11.

item.title: A sheriff, a felon and a conspiracy theorist walk into a hotel. They’re there for the same conference.

item.description: The Constitutional Sheriffs and Peace Officers Association conference in Las Vegas drew felons, disgraced politicians, election deniers and conspiracy theorists.

media:content.media:text: Sheriff Glenn of Hamilton of Sierra County, NM at the CSPOA Conference (Constitutional Sheriffs and Peace Officers Association) in Las Vegas, NV.
media:content.media:description: Former Sierra County, New Mexico, Sheriff Glenn Hamilton, part of a fringe group that sees sheriffs as more powerful than the federal government.

item.description: The former president perked up at certain remarks by members of the jury pool, while at other times he appeared ambivalent and staring straight ahead.

item.title: Arm and torso believed to be those of slain Milwaukee teen found along Lake Michigan
item.dc:creator: Antonio Planas
item.description: More human remains were discovered Thursday that are believed to be those of a 19-year-old Wisconsin woman who was dismembered and slain after she went on a date with the suspect, police said.

media:content.media:text: Sade Robinson.
media:content.media:description: Sade Robinson.

item.title: In Superman’s 'hometown,' a pastor vows to fight Satan’s influence at the local library
item.dc:creator: Mike Hixenbaugh
item.description: A battle over library books is dividing Metropolis, Illinois, which shares a name with Superman’s home. A pastor is framing the fight as a clash between good and evil.

media:content.media:text: A statue of Lois Lane and a Superman mural in Metropolis, Ill., and Bibles at the town's library.
media:content.media:description: For a half century, the small city of Metropolis, Ill., has marketed itself as the "Home of Superman." Now a fiery clash over its public library is testing its reputation for welcoming outsiders.

media:content.media:text: Pastor Brian Anderson calls of members of his congregation to show up at the library meeting.
media:content.media:description: Warning that evil was coming for Metropolis, Brian Anderson, a pastor, told his congregation on Jan. 13 that "the church needs to wake up."

media:content.media:text: A 15-foot Superman statue at the center of town in Metropolis.
media:content.media:description: Constructed of bronze rather than steel, a 15-foot Superman statue draws thousands of tourists to Metropolis every year.

media:content.media:text: Metropolis Public Library
media:content.media:description: Meetings of the Metropolis library board used to draw a resident or two, tops. In the months since Anderson's call to action, the board's meetings have been standing room only.

media:content.media:text: Rhonda James.
media:content.media:description: Rhonda James, Metropolis library board president, said she and her fellow members tried to address community concerns about the library's director without stirring controversy.

media:content.media:text: Rosemary Baxter is the former director of the Metropolis Public Library.
media:content.media:description: “We are here to serve and to honor God,” Rosemary Baxter said of her work for the Metropolis Public Library.

media:content.media:text: A mural in Metropolis commemorates the steamboat era.
media:content.media:description: On the shore of the Ohio river in southern Illinois, Metropolis is far closer — both geographically and culturally — to the cities of Nashville, Tenn., and St. Louis., Mo., than it is to Chicago.

media:content.media:text: Ford Loverin in his home.
media:content.media:description: "I almost laughed," Ford Loverin said of the claim that the library board wanted to host a drag queen story hour. "I thought, 'Oh, my God, in Metropolis? Really? Are you kidding me?'"

media:content.media:text: The banner of the Metropolis Planet features an image of Superman.
media:content.media:description: The Metropolis Planet has covered every twist and turn of the fight over the town's library.

media:content.media:text: Protesters support the library board on Feb. 20.
media:content.media:description: Responding to a call from county Democrats, residents show their support for the library board and the Library Bill of Rights.

media:content.media:text: Glenn Coram, pastor of Immanuel Baptist Church.
media:content.media:description: "All they're doing is saying, 'If somebody wants a book in the library, we'll give it to him,'" Glenn Coram, a pastor, said of the Metropolis library board. "How hard is that?"

media:content.media:text: Immanuel Baptist Church in Metropolis.
media:content.media:description: Glenn Coram said that he preaches the gospel of Jesus Christ at Immanuel Baptist, but that he does not believe his personal convictions should determine what other people can read at the library.

media:content.media:text: Richard Kruger is a lawyer in Metropolis.
media:content.media:description: In 52 years practicing law in Metropolis, Richard Kruger said he's never seen the community more divided.

media:content.media:text: Metropolis Mayor Don Canada.
media:content.media:description: Metropolis Mayor Don Canada said the library board is in need of a "fresh start."

media:content.media:text: Metropolis, Illinois
media:content.media:description: Some residents see the library fight as a test of what type city Metropolis is going to be moving forward — and who's welcome.

item.title: Judge denies Trump co-defendants' motions to dismiss charges in classified documents case
item.dc:creator: Megan Lebowitz and Dan Mangan, CNBC and Daniel Barnes
item.description: Judge Aileen Cannon in a Thursday filing denied motions by two of former President Donald Trump's co-defendants to dismiss charges in the classified documents case.

media:content.media:text: Trump aide Walt Nauta to be arraigned in Florida on Tuesday
media:content.media:description: Walt Nauta, aide to former President Donald Trump, arrives in Bedminster, N.J., in2023.

media:content.media:text: Carlos De Oliveira, center, an employee of Donald Trump's Mar-a-Lago estate, leaves a court appearance with attorney John Irving, left, at the James Lawrence King Federal Justice Building, Monday, July 31, 2023, in Miami. De Oliveira, Mar-a-Lago's property manager, was added last week to the indictment with Trump and the former president's valet, Walt Nauta, in the federal case alleging a plot to illegally keep top-secret records at Trump's Florida estate and thwart government efforts to retrieve them.
media:content.media:description: Carlos De Oliveira, center, leaves a court appearance with attorney John Irving, left, in Miami, in 2023.

item.title: Worsening allergies tied to climate change and severe weather
item.description: As doctors report more severe allergy symptoms in patients, scientists are blaming climate change and severe weather. NBC News' Anne Thompson reports.
